elements.content: A dual-emissive optical sensor based on the fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR) technique has been demonstrated to have significant advantages of high sensitivity and reliability. Here, we designed and successfully prepared a self-calibrated optical luminescent thermometer of CsPbBr3 quantum dot (QD) encapsulated lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Eu-BTC), and their phase compositions and luminescence properties have been characterized. Different thermo-response luminescence behaviors originating from the photoluminescence of CsPbBr3 QDs at 528 nm and the 5D0–7F2 emission of Eu3+ at 618 nm were investigated in the temperature range of 20–100 °C, in which the dual-emissive temperature-dependent emissions can serve as a ratiometric thermometer for accurate temperature monitoring applications. Significantly, the as-obtained CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC hybrid exhibited a high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C–1 at 20 °C and excellent temperature resolution of 0.004 °C in the measured temperature range, indicating its superiority as a ratiometric luminescent thermometer for temperature sensing. The related luminescent sensing mechanism of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC is also discussed, and this work provides an effective strategy for the rational design of a reliable and stable thermometer by integrating CsPbBr3 QDs and a carrier of a luminescent lanthanide organic framework.
elements.clean_text: A dual-emissive optical sensor based on the fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR) technique has been demonstrated to have significant advantages of high sensitivity and reliability. Here, we designed and successfully prepared a self-calibrated optical luminescent thermometer of CsPbBr3 quantum dot (QD) encapsulated lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Eu-BTC), and their phase compositions and luminescence properties have been characterized. Different thermo-response luminescence behaviors originating from the photoluminescence of CsPbBr3 QDs at 528 nm and the 5D0-7F2 emission of Eu3+ at 618 nm were investigated in the temperature range of 20-100 °C, in which the dual-emissive temperature-dependent emissions can serve as a ratiometric thermometer for accurate temperature monitoring applications. Significantly, the as-obtained CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC hybrid exhibited a high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C-1 at 20 °C and excellent temperature resolution of 0.004 °C in the measured temperature range, indicating its superiority as a ratiometric luminescent thermometer for temperature sensing. The related luminescent sensing mechanism of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC is also discussed, and this work provides an effective strategy for the rational design of a reliable and stable thermometer by integrating CsPbBr3 QDs and a carrier of a luminescent lanthanide organic framework.

elements.content: A dual-emissive CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC with FIR self-calibrated temperature-sensing activities has been prepared through a liquid-phase synthetic route and exhibited high relative sensitivity and excellent cyclic sensing stability, serving as an ultrastable ratiometric thermometer.
elements.clean_text: A dual-emissive CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC with FIR self-calibrated temperature-sensing activities has been prepared through a liquid-phase synthetic route and exhibited high relative sensitivity and excellent cyclic sensing stability, serving as an ultrastable ratiometric thermometer.

elements.content: Noncontact temperature sensing based on fast-response optical thermometry has attracted tremendous research interest due to its accuracy and effective real-time temperature-sensing behaviors. Many specific strategies have been widely developed aiming to promote the fast-response sensing performance, by monitoring the change in spectral shift, emission intensity, fluorescence lifetime, or fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR). Among these strategies, the FIR technique, applying the fluorescence intensity ratio of two temperature-dependent emitters, usually exhibits superior stability in self-referencing optical sensing performance in comparison to single-wavelength temperature-dependent emitters. The single-luminescence sensing system is more susceptible to interruption by environmental factors, such as the probe concentration, excitation intensity, and fluorescence efficiency, leading to an inaccurate estimation of temperature. The FIR between 2H11/2 → 4I15/2 and 2S3/2 → 4I15/2 emissions of Er3+ in NaYF4:Er3+,Yb3+ nanoparticles has been developed to serve as a nanothermometer to detect the temperature change of a cancer cell in the medical field. Generally, high relative temperature sensitivity (S r) is used as one of the most important parameters to evaluate the sensing performance of optical thermometers. The rational design of dual-emissive FIR-based sensitive nanoscale thermometric materials acting as nanothermometers with high luminescent efficiency and high sensing performance holds great significance for potential bioapplications at the subcellular level.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Noncontact temperature sensing based on fast-response optical thermometry has attracted tremendous research interest due to its accuracy and effective real-time temperature-sensing behaviors. Many specific strategies have been widely developed aiming to promote the fast-response sensing performance, by monitoring the change in spectral shift, emission intensity, fluorescence lifetime, or fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR). Among these strategies, the FIR technique, applying the fluorescence intensity ratio of two temperature-dependent emitters, usually exhibits superior stability in self-referencing optical sensing performance in comparison to single-wavelength temperature-dependent emitters. The single-luminescence sensing system is more susceptible to interruption by environmental factors, such as the probe concentration, excitation intensity, and fluorescence efficiency, leading to an inaccurate estimation of temperature. The FIR between 2H11/2 → 4I15/2 and 2S3/2 → 4I15/2 emissions of Er3+ in NaYF4:Er3+,Yb3+ nanoparticles has been developed to serve as a nanothermometer to detect the temperature change of a cancer cell in the medical field. Generally, high relative temperature sensitivity (S r) is used as one of the most important parameters to evaluate the sensing performance of optical thermometers. The rational design of dual-emissive FIR-based sensitive nanoscale thermometric materials acting as nanothermometers with high luminescent efficiency and high sensing performance holds great significance for potential bioapplications at the subcellular level.

elements.content: Up to now, various luminescent materials such as rare earth or transition metal ion activated inorganic phosphors, metal–organic framework (MOF) compounds, and quantum dots (QDs) have been developed as optical thermometers. Recently, perovskite CsPbX3 (X = Cl, Br, I) QDs have shown intriguing emitting characteristics and exhibited unprecedented progress in optical fields due to their stable luminescence properties, high luminescence efficiency, and high color purity. Especially, the luminescence properties of perovskite QDs can be tuned to cover the entire visible region by adjusting the crystal size and chemical compositions. Moreover, green-emitting CsPbBr3 QDs have attracted great attention in various luminescence applications due to their high photoluminescence quantum yields. However, the intrinsic poor solvent stability has put forward a significant obstacle to their practical applications. MOFs, as a type of highly ordered crystalline material, are constructed from the self-assembly of metal or metal clusters and organic ligands, exhibiting specific characteristics including a regular porous structure, large surface area, and tunable porosity. Moreover, by the introduction of luminescent centers into the metal nodes or organic ligands or by the grafting of luminescent guest molecules, excellent skeleton- or guest-induced luminescence properties can be obtained. For example, MOFs have been illustrated to be promising candidates for encapsulating luminescence dye molecules and carbon dots for temperature-sensing applications. Thus, it would be a very appealing strategy to encapsulate unstable CsPbBr3 QDs with superior luminescence behavior into a lanthanide-based MOF structure to target a novel dual-emissive FIR system featuring synergistic luminescence sensing performance with both excellent stability and high sensitivity.
elements.clean_text: Up to now, various luminescent materials such as rare earth or transition metal ion activated inorganic phosphors, metal-organic framework (MOF) compounds, and quantum dots (QDs) have been developed as optical thermometers. Recently, perovskite CsPbX3 (X = Cl, Br, I) QDs have shown intriguing emitting characteristics and exhibited unprecedented progress in optical fields due to their stable luminescence properties, high luminescence efficiency, and high color purity. Especially, the luminescence properties of perovskite QDs can be tuned to cover the entire visible region by adjusting the crystal size and chemical compositions. Moreover, green-emitting CsPbBr3 QDs have attracted great attention in various luminescence applications due to their high photoluminescence quantum yields. However, the intrinsic poor solvent stability has put forward a significant obstacle to their practical applications. MOFs, as a type of highly ordered crystalline material, are constructed from the self-assembly of metal or metal clusters and organic ligands, exhibiting specific characteristics including a regular porous structure, large surface area, and tunable porosity. Moreover, by the introduction of luminescent centers into the metal nodes or organic ligands or by the grafting of luminescent guest molecules, excellent skeleton- or guest-induced luminescence properties can be obtained. For example, MOFs have been illustrated to be promising candidates for encapsulating luminescence dye molecules and carbon dots for temperature-sensing applications. Thus, it would be a very appealing strategy to encapsulate unstable CsPbBr3 QDs with superior luminescence behavior into a lanthanide-based MOF structure to target a novel dual-emissive FIR system featuring synergistic luminescence sensing performance with both excellent stability and high sensitivity.

elements.content: Herein, a novel dual-emissive CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated Eu-MOF material has been successfully prepared through a simple liquid-phase synthetic route with expected FIR self-calibrated temperature sensing activities, in which the CsPbBr3 QDs display a thermo-quenching response, while the Eu3+ ions in the Eu-MOF show an opposite thermo-enhancing luminescence property when the temperature is increased. Accordingly, it is demonstrated that the thermo-response luminescence intensity ratio of CsPbBr3 QDs to Eu3+ emitters shows an exponential function versus temperature changes, which can effectively serve as an ultrastable self-calibrating temperature sensor. The as-obtained novel CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC thermometer shows a very high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C–1 at 20 °C and excellent cyclic sensing stability.
elements.clean_text: Herein, a novel dual-emissive CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated Eu-MOF material has been successfully prepared through a simple liquid-phase synthetic route with expected FIR self-calibrated temperature sensing activities, in which the CsPbBr3 QDs display a thermo-quenching response, while the Eu3+ ions in the Eu-MOF show an opposite thermo-enhancing luminescence property when the temperature is increased. Accordingly, it is demonstrated that the thermo-response luminescence intensity ratio of CsPbBr3 QDs to Eu3+ emitters shows an exponential function versus temperature changes, which can effectively serve as an ultrastable self-calibrating temperature sensor. The as-obtained novel CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC thermometer shows a very high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C-1 at 20 °C and excellent cyclic sensing stability.

elements.content: All starting materials were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. In a typical synthesis, PbBr2 (367.01 mg, 1 mmol) was dissolved in a solution containing DMF (20 mL), hexanoic acid (232.32 mg, 2 mmol), and octylamine (258.48 mg, 2 mmol). Subsequently, 1 mL of a 0.4 mol/L Cs-oleate solution prepared by mixing Cs2CO3 (652.05 mg, 2 mmol) with octadecene (10 mL) and oleic acid (1.13 g, 4 mmol) at 150 °C for 3 h was added to this solution, and the mixture was stirred evenly. Then, Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O (178 mg, 0.4 mmol) and NaAc (164 mg, 2 mmol) were added to the mixture to form a metal precursor solution. Then, trimesic acid (H3BTC) (188 mg, 0.90 mmol) was introduced into the Eu3+ ion containing metal precursor mixture with continuous stirring at room temperature, and a large amount of a white suspension was immediately produced. After vigorous stirring for about 12 h, 0.5 mL of the mixed solution was placed in a flask containing 20 mL of toluene, and the as-prepared CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC product was finally collected by centrifugation, washed three times with ethyl acetate, and dried under vacuum conditions at 60 °C for 2 h. provides the in situ preparation process for the CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated in Eu-BTC matrix.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Preparation

All starting materials were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. In a typical synthesis, PbBr2 (367.01 mg, 1 mmol) was dissolved in a solution containing DMF (20 mL), hexanoic acid (232.32 mg, 2 mmol), and octylamine (258.48 mg, 2 mmol). Subsequently, 1 mL of a 0.4 mol/L Cs-oleate solution prepared by mixing Cs2CO3 (652.05 mg, 2 mmol) with octadecene (10 mL) and oleic acid (1.13 g, 4 mmol) at 150 °C for 3 h was added to this solution, and the mixture was stirred evenly. Then, Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O (178 mg, 0.4 mmol) and NaAc (164 mg, 2 mmol) were added to the mixture to form a metal precursor solution. Then, trimesic acid (H3BTC) (188 mg, 0.90 mmol) was introduced into the Eu3+ ion containing metal precursor mixture with continuous stirring at room temperature, and a large amount of a white suspension was immediately produced. After vigorous stirring for about 12 h, 0.5 mL of the mixed solution was placed in a flask containing 20 mL of toluene, and the as-prepared CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC product was finally collected by centrifugation, washed three times with ethyl acetate, and dried under vacuum conditions at 60 °C for 2 h.  provides the in situ preparation process for the CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated in Eu-BTC matrix.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Illustration for the Preparation Process of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC

elements.content: The morphology of the sample was characterized by a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi SU-8010). The phase structures of the perovskite CsPbBr3 QDs and CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composite were investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measured on an X’Pert Pro MRDDY2094 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) in the 2θ range of 5–60° under a voltage of 30 kV and a current of 40 mA. The internal structure of the sample was investigated by a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100F). The chemical composition of the sample was determined by an energy dispersive spectroscope (EDS) attached to the SEM instrument. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were carried out on a fluorescence spectrophotometer (FluoroMax-4, HORIBA) equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. The temperature-dependent luminescence measurements were performed using the same Horiba fluorescence spectrophotometer by attaching an electric heating furnace (Luma 40/Horiba4) into the sample chamber with circulating cooling water pipes to control the temperature. During the measurement, the temperature increased from 20 to 100 °C with an interval of 10 °C and the temperatures were kept for 3 min at each data point.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

The morphology of the sample was characterized by a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi SU-8010). The phase structures of the perovskite CsPbBr3 QDs and CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composite were investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measured on an X'Pert Pro MRDDY2094 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) in the 2θ range of 5-60° under a voltage of 30 kV and a current of 40 mA. The internal structure of the sample was investigated by a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100F). The chemical composition of the sample was determined by an energy dispersive spectroscope (EDS) attached to the SEM instrument. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were carried out on a fluorescence spectrophotometer (FluoroMax-4, HORIBA) equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. The temperature-dependent luminescence measurements were performed using the same Horiba fluorescence spectrophotometer by attaching an electric heating furnace (Luma 40/Horiba4) into the sample chamber with circulating cooling water pipes to control the temperature. During the measurement, the temperature increased from 20 to 100 °C with an interval of 10 °C and the temperatures were kept for 3 min at each data point.

elements.content: a displays the SEM image of the as-formed CsPbBr3@EuBTC composite, which is assembled from numerous CsPbBr3@EuBTC nanoparticles. The simulated XRD patterns of Eu-BTC and CsPbBr3 QDs and the experimental XRD patterns of as-prepared CsPbBr3 QDs and CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composites are shown in b. The presence of CsPbBr3 QDs in CsPbBr3@EuBTC can be exactly confirmed by the two characteristic diffraction peaks centered at around 21.6 and 30.8° corresponding to the (020) and (220) reflection planes of the standard CsPbBr3 QDs, respectively. The XRD diffraction peaks of the as-prepared CsPbBr3 QDs and CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composites can be indexed to those of the simulated XRD pattern of CsPbBr3 (PDF 54-0751) and Eu-BTC (CCDC No. 290771), respectively, confirming the successful formation of the designed crystalline phase of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC as expected under in situ stirring and heating conditions. The low diffraction intensities of the Eu-BTC patterns are ascribed to the poor crystallinity of the phase formed at room temperature. However, a small amount of a CsPb2Br5 (PDF 25-0211) phase coexisted in the final product from the combination of CsPbBr3 and excess PbBr2 with the characteristic diffraction peaks marked with triangle symbols, but it does not show emission as reported. c shows the HRTEM image of the CsPbBr3@EuBTC composite, revealing the distribution of CsPbBr3 QDs formed in situ in the Eu-BTC MOF matrix. d shows an HRTEM image of the CsPbBr3@EuBTC, and it can be seen that the CsPbBr3 QDs are wrapped by crystalline Eu-BTC MOF and a clear lattice spacing of 0.284 nm can be observed, corresponding to the (002) facet of the perovskite CsPbBr3 QD structure. e–j show elemental maps of the prepared CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composites. The results demonstrated that the Cs, Pb, Br, Eu, and O elements are equally distributed in the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composite during the formation of the composite, confirming the reasonable prediction and a feasible in situ strategy to prepare the anticipated CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated Eu-BTC composite for luminescence applications.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure and Luminescence Characterizations

 a displays the SEM image of the as-formed CsPbBr3@EuBTC composite, which is assembled from numerous CsPbBr3@EuBTC nanoparticles. The simulated XRD patterns of Eu-BTC and CsPbBr3 QDs and the experimental XRD patterns of as-prepared CsPbBr3 QDs and CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composites are shown in b. The presence of CsPbBr3 QDs in CsPbBr3@EuBTC can be exactly confirmed by the two characteristic diffraction peaks centered at around 21.6 and 30.8° corresponding to the (020) and (220) reflection planes of the standard CsPbBr3 QDs, respectively. The XRD diffraction peaks of the as-prepared CsPbBr3 QDs and CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composites can be indexed to those of the simulated XRD pattern of CsPbBr3 (PDF 54-0751) and Eu-BTC (CCDC No. 290771), respectively, confirming the successful formation of the designed crystalline phase of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC as expected under in situ stirring and heating conditions. The low diffraction intensities of the Eu-BTC patterns are ascribed to the poor crystallinity of the phase formed at room temperature. However, a small amount of a CsPb2Br5 (PDF 25-0211) phase coexisted in the final product from the combination of CsPbBr3 and excess PbBr2 with the characteristic diffraction peaks marked with triangle symbols, but it does not show emission as reported. c shows the HRTEM image of the CsPbBr3@EuBTC composite, revealing the distribution of CsPbBr3 QDs formed in situ in the Eu-BTC MOF matrix. d shows an HRTEM image of the CsPbBr3@EuBTC, and it can be seen that the CsPbBr3 QDs are wrapped by crystalline Eu-BTC MOF and a clear lattice spacing of 0.284 nm can be observed, corresponding to the (002) facet of the perovskite CsPbBr3 QD structure. e-j show elemental maps of the prepared CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composites. The results demonstrated that the Cs, Pb, Br, Eu, and O elements are equally distributed in the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composite during the formation of the composite, confirming the reasonable prediction and a feasible in situ strategy to prepare the anticipated CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated Eu-BTC composite for luminescence applications.

elements.content: (a) SEM image of a CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC sample. (b) Simulated XRD patterns of Eu-BTC (top line) with CCDC No. 290771 retrieved by the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, the CsPbBr3 QDs (bottom line) with a the powder diffraction file (PDF) number 54-0751, and the experimental XRD patterns of the as-prepared CsPbBr3 QDs (light green line) and CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC (orange line). (c) TEM and (d) HRTEM images of the CsPbBr3@EuBTC composite. (e) Selected SEM image and the corresponding elemental mapping diagrams of (f) Cs, (g) Pb, (h) Br, (i) Eu, and (j) O in the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composite.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) SEM image of a CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC sample. (b) Simulated XRD patterns of Eu-BTC (top line) with CCDC No. 290771 retrieved by the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, the CsPbBr3 QDs (bottom line) with a the powder diffraction file (PDF) number 54-0751, and the experimental XRD patterns of the as-prepared CsPbBr3 QDs (light green line) and CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC (orange line). (c) TEM and (d) HRTEM images of the CsPbBr3@EuBTC composite. (e) Selected SEM image and the corresponding elemental mapping diagrams of (f) Cs, (g) Pb, (h) Br, (i) Eu, and (j) O in the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composite.

elements.content: The room-temperature PLE and PL spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC are shown in . The broad PL emission over the range of 500–580 nm originates from CsPbBr3 QDs encapsulated in Eu-BTC, and the two sharp emission peaks located at 593 and 618 nm are assigned to the 5D0–7F1 and 5D0–7F2 transitions of Eu3+ ions in Eu-BTC, respectively. The PLE spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC were monitored by the characteristic emissions of CsPbBr3 QDs and Eu3+ at 529 and 618 nm, which shows that the PLE spectrum of CsPbBr3 QDs overlaps with that of Eu3+ ions, and the CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF sample exhibited an excellent dual-emissive property on excitation at about 339 nm. The excited electrons at the 5L6 level of Eu3+ ions relaxed to the 5D0 level to yield the red emission, while the recombination of electron–hole pairs in CsPbBr3 constituent resulted in a green emission.
elements.clean_text: The room-temperature PLE and PL spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC are shown in . The broad PL emission over the range of 500-580 nm originates from CsPbBr3 QDs encapsulated in Eu-BTC, and the two sharp emission peaks located at 593 and 618 nm are assigned to the 5D0-7F1 and 5D0-7F2 transitions of Eu3+ ions in Eu-BTC, respectively. The PLE spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC were monitored by the characteristic emissions of CsPbBr3 QDs and Eu3+ at 529 and 618 nm, which shows that the PLE spectrum of CsPbBr3 QDs overlaps with that of Eu3+ ions, and the CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF sample exhibited an excellent dual-emissive property on excitation at about 339 nm. The excited electrons at the 5L6 level of Eu3+ ions relaxed to the 5D0 level to yield the red emission, while the recombination of electron-hole pairs in CsPbBr3 constituent resulted in a green emission.

elements.content: PLE spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF (λem = 529 and 618 nm) and PL spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF at the excitation wavelengths (λex = 339 and 537 nm).
elements.clean_text: 2  PLE spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF (λem = 529 and 618 nm) and PL spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF at the excitation wavelengths (λex = 339 and 537 nm).

elements.content: The PL emission spectra of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite measured between 20 and 100 °C are shown in a. As can be seen, the characteristic green emission of CsPbBr3 QDs centered at around 528 nm decreased gradually as the temperature increased, while the CsPbBr3 QDs did not show any change in PL peak position. In contrast, the PL emission intensity of Eu3+ ions at 618 nm increased as the temperature increased. The result is quite different from those of a previous report, in which the Eu3+ emission derived from electron transitions usually exhibited a “weak coupling” effect with low temperature-sensing response. Such a significant temperature response of Eu3+ ions in CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC might be related to the high luminescence efficiency of the encapsulated guest CsPbBr3 QD phase and the host skeleton limiting effect of the Eu-BTC matrix. The two emission centers seem to be independent without energy transfer between them in this bulk composite. Thus, the opposite temperature-sensing behaviors of CsPbBr3 QDs and skeleton Eu3+ ions will benefit the application of an optical nanothermometer based on the FIR of Eu3+ ions (618 nm) to CsPbBr3 (528 nm).
elements.clean_text:
Dual-Emissive Temperature Sensing Performance of CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF

The PL emission spectra of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite measured between 20 and 100 °C are shown in a. As can be seen, the characteristic green emission of CsPbBr3 QDs centered at around 528 nm decreased gradually as the temperature increased, while the CsPbBr3 QDs did not show any change in PL peak position. In contrast, the PL emission intensity of Eu3+ ions at 618 nm increased as the temperature increased. The result is quite different from those of a previous report, in which the Eu3+ emission derived from electron transitions usually exhibited a "weak coupling" effect with low temperature-sensing response. Such a significant temperature response of Eu3+ ions in CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC might be related to the high luminescence efficiency of the encapsulated guest CsPbBr3 QD phase and the host skeleton limiting effect of the Eu-BTC matrix. The two emission centers seem to be independent without energy transfer between them in this bulk composite. Thus, the opposite temperature-sensing behaviors of CsPbBr3 QDs and skeleton Eu3+ ions will benefit the application of an optical nanothermometer based on the FIR of Eu3+ ions (618 nm) to CsPbBr3 (528 nm).

elements.content: (a) Temperature-dependent PL spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC in the temperature range of 20–100 °C excited at 339 nm (inset: the CIE (x, y) coordinate diagram of emission colors at various temperatures). (b) Integrated emission intensities of CsPbBr3 QDs and Eu3+: 5D0–7F2 versus various temperatures.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Temperature-dependent PL spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC in the temperature range of 20-100 °C excited at 339 nm (inset: the CIE (x, y) coordinate diagram of emission colors at various temperatures). (b) Integrated emission intensities of CsPbBr3 QDs and Eu3+: 5D0-7F2 versus various temperatures.

elements.content: a illustrates the chromaticity diagram of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC at different temperatures. It can be found that with an increase in temperature, the emissive colors evolved from green (0.275, 0.674) to orange (0.536, 0.423) (inset in a). b illustrates the relative luminescent intensity ratio of Eu3+ ions (618 nm) to CsPbBr3 (528 nm) versus temperature, and the results can be well fitted by the exponential function equation (a) I 618 nm I 528 nm = − 0.536 + 1.422 × e 0.031 T where I 618 nm and I 528 nm denote the emission intensities of Eu3+ ions in Eu-BTC and CsPbBr3 QDs, respectively, and T is the temperature. Such a fitting result with R 2 = 0.995 demonstrated that the luminescent emission intensity ratio I 618 nm/I 528 nm from CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF nanoparticles can be intrinsically used for temperature monitoring, showing an excellent ratiometric temperature-sensing ability.
elements.clean_text: a illustrates the chromaticity diagram of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC at different temperatures. It can be found that with an increase in temperature, the emissive colors evolved from green (0.275, 0.674) to orange (0.536, 0.423) (inset in a). b illustrates the relative luminescent intensity ratio of Eu3+ ions (618 nm) to CsPbBr3 (528 nm) versus temperature, and the results can be well fitted by the exponential function equation (a)         I   618  nm       I   528  nm     = - 0.536 + 1.422 ×   e   0.031 T     1 where I 618nm and I 528nm denote the emission intensities of Eu3+ ions in Eu-BTC and CsPbBr3 QDs, respectively, and T is the temperature. Such a fitting result with R 2 = 0.995 demonstrated that the luminescent emission intensity ratio I 618nm/I 528nm from CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF nanoparticles can be intrinsically used for temperature monitoring, showing an excellent ratiometric temperature-sensing ability.

elements.content: (a) Measured and exponentially fitted plots of FIR (I 618 nm/I 528 nm) versus temperature. (b) Absolute sensitivity S a and relative sensitivity S r versus temperature. (c) Calculation of temperature resolution. (d) Corresponding cycle measurements of the FIR between 20 and 65 °C (I 618 nm/I 528 nm).
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Measured and exponentially fitted plots of FIR (I 618nm/I 528nm) versus temperature. (b) Absolute sensitivity S a and relative sensitivity S r versus temperature. (c) Calculation of temperature resolution. (d) Corresponding cycle measurements of the FIR between 20 and 65 °C (I 618nm/I 528nm).

elements.content: In addition, we also calculated the absolute sensitivity (S a) and relative sensitivity (S r) to quantitatively evaluate the ratiometric temperature-sensing activity of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanothermometer. S a and S r can be calculated by the equations S a = | ∂Δ ∂ T | S r = | S a Δ | where Δ is used to represent the PL intensity ratio I 618 nm/I 528 nm, and T is the temperature. As a result, b shows the calculated S a and S r values as a function of temperature. It can be easily observed that the maximum value of S r is 3.9% °C–1 measured at 20 °C, which is higher than those of most of the reported MOF-based ratiometric thermometers (). In addition, the temperature resolution (δT), another crucial parameter for evaluating the thermometer, can be estimated from the equation δ T = 1 S r ∂Δ Δ where δΔ/Δ denotes the relative error in the thermometric parameter measurements defined by the experimental detection equipment. The fluorescence spectrometer used has a signal to noise ratio of 16000:1, which means that the value of δΔ/Δ is about 0.0125%. The calculated δT curve of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC versus temperature is shown in c, which also indicates that δT is better than 0.004 °C across the entire measured temperature range. To evaluate the reversibility of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite toward temperature switching operations, the luminescent intensities of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC upon heating/cooling at 20 and 65 °C were recorded. The cycling experimental results are shown in d and indicate that the luminescent switching operation can be repeated for at least six consecutive cycles without significant change, illustrating its excellent reversibility and reliability as an optical sensor for thermometer applications. The above results demonstrate that the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite can serve as an optical ratiometric nanothermometer with high relative sensitivity and temperature resolution for potential temperature-sensing applications.
elements.clean_text: In addition, we also calculated the absolute sensitivity (S a) and relative sensitivity (S r) to quantitatively evaluate the ratiometric temperature-sensing activity of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanothermometer. S a and S r can be calculated by the equations       S   a   =  |   ∂Δ   ∂ T   |    2        S   r   =  |     S   a     Δ   |    3 where Δ is used to represent the PL intensity ratio I 618nm/I 528nm, and T is the temperature. As a result, b shows the calculated S a and S r values as a function of temperature. It can be easily observed that the maximum value of S r is 3.9% °C-1 measured at 20 °C, which is higher than those of most of the reported MOF-based ratiometric thermometers (). In addition, the temperature resolution (δT), another crucial parameter for evaluating the thermometer, can be estimated from the equation 4    δ T =   1     S   r       ∂Δ   Δ     where δΔ/Δ denotes the relative error in the thermometric parameter measurements defined by the experimental detection equipment. The fluorescence spectrometer used has a signal to noise ratio of 16000:1, which means that the value of δΔ/Δ is about 0.0125%. The calculated δT curve of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC versus temperature is shown in c, which also indicates that δT is better than 0.004 °C across the entire measured temperature range. To evaluate the reversibility of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite toward temperature switching operations, the luminescent intensities of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC upon heating/cooling at 20 and 65 °C were recorded. The cycling experimental results are shown in d and indicate that the luminescent switching operation can be repeated for at least six consecutive cycles without significant change, illustrating its excellent reversibility and reliability as an optical sensor for thermometer applications. The above results demonstrate that the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite can serve as an optical ratiometric nanothermometer with high relative sensitivity and temperature resolution for potential temperature-sensing applications.

In summary, we have successfully prepared a self-calibrated optical luminescent nanothermometer of CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Eu-BTC). The different thermo-response luminescence behaviors of CsPbBr3 QD emission at 528 nm and 5D0–7F2 emission of Eu3+ at 618 nm were investigated in the temperature range of 20–100 °C. The as-obtained CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC hybrid exhibits excellent FIR ratiometric temperature-sensing properties with a high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C–1 at 20 °C and an excellent temperature resolution of 0.004 °C, indicating its superiority to serve as a nanothermometer for optical temperature sensing. This work provides an effective strategy for the rational design and synthesis of a reliable and stable thermometer by integrating CsPbBr3 QDs and a carrier of a luminescent lanthanide organic framework.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully prepared a self-calibrated optical luminescent nanothermometer of CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Eu-BTC). The different thermo-response luminescence behaviors of CsPbBr3 QD emission at 528 nm and 5D0-7F2 emission of Eu3+ at 618 nm were investigated in the temperature range of 20-100 °C. The as-obtained CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC hybrid exhibits excellent FIR ratiometric temperature-sensing properties with a high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C-1 at 20 °C and an excellent temperature resolution of 0.004 °C, indicating its superiority to serve as a nanothermometer for optical temperature sensing. This work provides an effective strategy for the rational design and synthesis of a reliable and stable thermometer by integrating CsPbBr3 QDs and a carrier of a luminescent lanthanide organic framework.

elements.content: The authors declare no competing financial interest.
elements.clean_text: The authors declare no competing financial interest.

cln_elements.content:
A dual-emissive optical sensor based on the fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR) technique has been demonstrated to have significant advantages of high sensitivity and reliability. Here, we designed and successfully prepared a self-calibrated optical luminescent thermometer of CsPbBr3 quantum dot (QD) encapsulated lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Eu-BTC), and their phase compositions and luminescence properties have been characterized. Different thermo-response luminescence behaviors originating from the photoluminescence of CsPbBr3 QDs at 528 nm and the 5D0–7F2 emission of Eu3+ at 618 nm were investigated in the temperature range of 20–100 °C, in which the dual-emissive temperature-dependent emissions can serve as a ratiometric thermometer for accurate temperature monitoring applications. Significantly, the as-obtained CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC hybrid exhibited a high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C–1 at 20 °C and excellent temperature resolution of 0.004 °C in the measured temperature range, indicating its superiority as a ratiometric luminescent thermometer for temperature sensing. The related luminescent sensing mechanism of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC is also discussed, and this work provides an effective strategy for the rational design of a reliable and stable thermometer by integrating CsPbBr3 QDs and a carrier of a luminescent lanthanide organic framework.

Herein, a novel dual-emissive CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated Eu-MOF material has been successfully prepared through a simple liquid-phase synthetic route with expected FIR self-calibrated temperature sensing activities, in which the CsPbBr3 QDs display a thermo-quenching response, while the Eu3+ ions in the Eu-MOF show an opposite thermo-enhancing luminescence property when the temperature is increased. Accordingly, it is demonstrated that the thermo-response luminescence intensity ratio of CsPbBr3 QDs to Eu3+ emitters shows an exponential function versus temperature changes, which can effectively serve as an ultrastable self-calibrating temperature sensor. The as-obtained novel CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC thermometer shows a very high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C–1 at 20 °C and excellent cyclic sensing stability.

a illustrates the chromaticity diagram of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC at different temperatures. It can be found that with an increase in temperature, the emissive colors evolved from green (0.275, 0.674) to orange (0.536, 0.423) (inset in a). b illustrates the relative luminescent intensity ratio of Eu3+ ions (618 nm) to CsPbBr3 (528 nm) versus temperature, and the results can be well fitted by the exponential function equation (a) I 618 nm I 528 nm = − 0.536 + 1.422 × e 0.031 T where I 618 nm and I 528 nm denote the emission intensities of Eu3+ ions in Eu-BTC and CsPbBr3 QDs, respectively, and T is the temperature. Such a fitting result with R 2 = 0.995 demonstrated that the luminescent emission intensity ratio I 618 nm/I 528 nm from CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF nanoparticles can be intrinsically used for temperature monitoring, showing an excellent ratiometric temperature-sensing ability.

In addition, we also calculated the absolute sensitivity (S a) and relative sensitivity (S r) to quantitatively evaluate the ratiometric temperature-sensing activity of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanothermometer. S a and S r can be calculated by the equations S a = | ∂Δ ∂ T | S r = | S a Δ | where Δ is used to represent the PL intensity ratio I 618 nm/I 528 nm, and T is the temperature. As a result, b shows the calculated S a and S r values as a function of temperature. It can be easily observed that the maximum value of S r is 3.9% °C–1 measured at 20 °C, which is higher than those of most of the reported MOF-based ratiometric thermometers (). In addition, the temperature resolution (δT), another crucial parameter for evaluating the thermometer, can be estimated from the equation δ T = 1 S r ∂Δ Δ where δΔ/Δ denotes the relative error in the thermometric parameter measurements defined by the experimental detection equipment. The fluorescence spectrometer used has a signal to noise ratio of 16000:1, which means that the value of δΔ/Δ is about 0.0125%. The calculated δT curve of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC versus temperature is shown in c, which also indicates that δT is better than 0.004 °C across the entire measured temperature range. To evaluate the reversibility of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite toward temperature switching operations, the luminescent intensities of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC upon heating/cooling at 20 and 65 °C were recorded. The cycling experimental results are shown in d and indicate that the luminescent switching operation can be repeated for at least six consecutive cycles without significant change, illustrating its excellent reversibility and reliability as an optical sensor for thermometer applications. The above results demonstrate that the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite can serve as an optical ratiometric nanothermometer with high relative sensitivity and temperature resolution for potential temperature-sensing applications.

Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully prepared a self-calibrated optical luminescent nanothermometer of CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Eu-BTC). The different thermo-response luminescence behaviors of CsPbBr3 QD emission at 528 nm and 5D0–7F2 emission of Eu3+ at 618 nm were investigated in the temperature range of 20–100 °C. The as-obtained CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC hybrid exhibits excellent FIR ratiometric temperature-sensing properties with a high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C–1 at 20 °C and an excellent temperature resolution of 0.004 °C, indicating its superiority to serve as a nanothermometer for optical temperature sensing. This work provides an effective strategy for the rational design and synthesis of a reliable and stable thermometer by integrating CsPbBr3 QDs and a carrier of a luminescent lanthanide organic framework.
cln_elements.clean_text:
A dual-emissive optical sensor based on the fluorescence intensity ratio (FIR) technique has been demonstrated to have significant advantages of high sensitivity and reliability. Here, we designed and successfully prepared a self-calibrated optical luminescent thermometer of CsPbBr3 quantum dot (QD) encapsulated lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Eu-BTC), and their phase compositions and luminescence properties have been characterized. Different thermo-response luminescence behaviors originating from the photoluminescence of CsPbBr3 QDs at 528 nm and the 5D0-7F2 emission of Eu3+ at 618 nm were investigated in the temperature range of 20-100 °C, in which the dual-emissive temperature-dependent emissions can serve as a ratiometric thermometer for accurate temperature monitoring applications. Significantly, the as-obtained CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC hybrid exhibited a high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C-1 at 20 °C and excellent temperature resolution of 0.004 °C in the measured temperature range, indicating its superiority as a ratiometric luminescent thermometer for temperature sensing. The related luminescent sensing mechanism of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC is also discussed, and this work provides an effective strategy for the rational design of a reliable and stable thermometer by integrating CsPbBr3 QDs and a carrier of a luminescent lanthanide organic framework.

Herein, a novel dual-emissive CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated Eu-MOF material has been successfully prepared through a simple liquid-phase synthetic route with expected FIR self-calibrated temperature sensing activities, in which the CsPbBr3 QDs display a thermo-quenching response, while the Eu3+ ions in the Eu-MOF show an opposite thermo-enhancing luminescence property when the temperature is increased. Accordingly, it is demonstrated that the thermo-response luminescence intensity ratio of CsPbBr3 QDs to Eu3+ emitters shows an exponential function versus temperature changes, which can effectively serve as an ultrastable self-calibrating temperature sensor. The as-obtained novel CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC thermometer shows a very high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C-1 at 20 °C and excellent cyclic sensing stability.

 a illustrates the chromaticity diagram of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC at different temperatures. It can be found that with an increase in temperature, the emissive colors evolved from green (0.275, 0.674) to orange (0.536, 0.423) (inset in a). b illustrates the relative luminescent intensity ratio of Eu3+ ions (618 nm) to CsPbBr3 (528 nm) versus temperature, and the results can be well fitted by the exponential function equation (a)         I   618  nm       I   528  nm     = - 0.536 + 1.422 ×   e   0.031 T     1 where I 618nm and I 528nm denote the emission intensities of Eu3+ ions in Eu-BTC and CsPbBr3 QDs, respectively, and T is the temperature. Such a fitting result with R 2 = 0.995 demonstrated that the luminescent emission intensity ratio I 618nm/I 528nm from CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF nanoparticles can be intrinsically used for temperature monitoring, showing an excellent ratiometric temperature-sensing ability.

In addition, we also calculated the absolute sensitivity (S a) and relative sensitivity (S r) to quantitatively evaluate the ratiometric temperature-sensing activity of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanothermometer. S a and S r can be calculated by the equations       S   a   =  |   ∂Δ   ∂ T   |    2        S   r   =  |     S   a     Δ   |    3 where Δ is used to represent the PL intensity ratio I 618nm/I 528nm, and T is the temperature. As a result, b shows the calculated S a and S r values as a function of temperature. It can be easily observed that the maximum value of S r is 3.9% °C-1 measured at 20 °C, which is higher than those of most of the reported MOF-based ratiometric thermometers (). In addition, the temperature resolution (δT), another crucial parameter for evaluating the thermometer, can be estimated from the equation 4    δ T =   1     S   r       ∂Δ   Δ     where δΔ/Δ denotes the relative error in the thermometric parameter measurements defined by the experimental detection equipment. The fluorescence spectrometer used has a signal to noise ratio of 16000:1, which means that the value of δΔ/Δ is about 0.0125%. The calculated δT curve of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC versus temperature is shown in c, which also indicates that δT is better than 0.004 °C across the entire measured temperature range. To evaluate the reversibility of the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite toward temperature switching operations, the luminescent intensities of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC upon heating/cooling at 20 and 65 °C were recorded. The cycling experimental results are shown in d and indicate that the luminescent switching operation can be repeated for at least six consecutive cycles without significant change, illustrating its excellent reversibility and reliability as an optical sensor for thermometer applications. The above results demonstrate that the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC nanocomposite can serve as an optical ratiometric nanothermometer with high relative sensitivity and temperature resolution for potential temperature-sensing applications.

Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully prepared a self-calibrated optical luminescent nanothermometer of CsPbBr3 QD encapsulated lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Eu-BTC). The different thermo-response luminescence behaviors of CsPbBr3 QD emission at 528 nm and 5D0-7F2 emission of Eu3+ at 618 nm were investigated in the temperature range of 20-100 °C. The as-obtained CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC hybrid exhibits excellent FIR ratiometric temperature-sensing properties with a high relative sensitivity (S r) of 3.9% °C-1 at 20 °C and an excellent temperature resolution of 0.004 °C, indicating its superiority to serve as a nanothermometer for optical temperature sensing. This work provides an effective strategy for the rational design and synthesis of a reliable and stable thermometer by integrating CsPbBr3 QDs and a carrier of a luminescent lanthanide organic framework.

| Eu-MOF/Zn<sub>2</sub>GeO<sub>4</sub>:Mn<sup>2+</sup> | 20–90 °C | 4.1 % °C<sup>–1</sup> | [14] |
| Rh101@UiO-67 | 25–45 °C | 1.19% °C<sup>–1</sup> | [40] |
| UiO-66(Zr&Eu) film | 237–337 K | 4.26% K<sup>–1</sup> | [41] |
| Tb<sub>0.95</sub>Eu<sub>0.05</sub>(btb) | 10–320 K | 2.85% K<sup>–1</sup> | [42] |
| TbMOF@3%Eu_tfac | 225–375 K | 2.59% K<sup>–1</sup> | [43] |
| Zn<sub>1.90</sub>GeO<sub>4</sub>:0.02Mn<sup>2+</sup>,0.08Eu<sup>3+</sup> | 20–80 °C | 1.96% °C<sup>–1</sup> | [44] |
| Ca<sub>8</sub>ZnLa(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>7</sub>:Tb<sup>3+</sup>, Eu<sup>3+</sup> | 298–448 K | 0.53% K<sup>–1</sup> | [45] |

| CsPbBr<sub>3</sub>@Eu-BTC | 20–100 °C | 3.9% °C<sup>–1</sup> | this work |

<title>Schematic Illustration for the Preparation Process
of CsPbBr<sub>3</sub>@Eu-BTC</title>

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Illustration for the Preparation Process of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC

cln_elements.content: (a) SEM image of a CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC sample. (b) Simulated XRD patterns of Eu-BTC (top line) with CCDC No. 290771 retrieved by the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, the CsPbBr3 QDs (bottom line) with a the powder diffraction file (PDF) number 54-0751, and the experimental XRD patterns of the as-prepared CsPbBr3 QDs (light green line) and CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC (orange line). (c) TEM and (d) HRTEM images of the CsPbBr3@EuBTC composite. (e) Selected SEM image and the corresponding elemental mapping diagrams of (f) Cs, (g) Pb, (h) Br, (i) Eu, and (j) O in the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composite.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) SEM image of a CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC sample. (b) Simulated XRD patterns of Eu-BTC (top line) with CCDC No. 290771 retrieved by the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, the CsPbBr3 QDs (bottom line) with a the powder diffraction file (PDF) number 54-0751, and the experimental XRD patterns of the as-prepared CsPbBr3 QDs (light green line) and CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC (orange line). (c) TEM and (d) HRTEM images of the CsPbBr3@EuBTC composite. (e) Selected SEM image and the corresponding elemental mapping diagrams of (f) Cs, (g) Pb, (h) Br, (i) Eu, and (j) O in the CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC composite.

cln_elements.content: PLE spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF (λem = 529 and 618 nm) and PL spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF at the excitation wavelengths (λex = 339 and 537 nm).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  PLE spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF (λem = 529 and 618 nm) and PL spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-MOF at the excitation wavelengths (λex = 339 and 537 nm).

cln_elements.content: (a) Temperature-dependent PL spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC in the temperature range of 20–100 °C excited at 339 nm (inset: the CIE (x, y) coordinate diagram of emission colors at various temperatures). (b) Integrated emission intensities of CsPbBr3 QDs and Eu3+: 5D0–7F2 versus various temperatures.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Temperature-dependent PL spectra of CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC in the temperature range of 20-100 °C excited at 339 nm (inset: the CIE (x, y) coordinate diagram of emission colors at various temperatures). (b) Integrated emission intensities of CsPbBr3 QDs and Eu3+: 5D0-7F2 versus various temperatures.

cln_elements.content: (a) Measured and exponentially fitted plots of FIR (I 618 nm/I 528 nm) versus temperature. (b) Absolute sensitivity S a and relative sensitivity S r versus temperature. (c) Calculation of temperature resolution. (d) Corresponding cycle measurements of the FIR between 20 and 65 °C (I 618 nm/I 528 nm).
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Measured and exponentially fitted plots of FIR (I 618nm/I 528nm) versus temperature. (b) Absolute sensitivity S a and relative sensitivity S r versus temperature. (c) Calculation of temperature resolution. (d) Corresponding cycle measurements of the FIR between 20 and 65 °C (I 618nm/I 528nm).

metadata.title:
Dual-Emissive CsPbBr3@Eu-BTC Composite
for Self-Calibrating Temperature Sensing Application
